title: On the exceptional zeros of Rankin-Selberg L-functions

title_detail.value: On the exceptional zeros of Rankin-Selberg L-functions

summary:
The main objects of study in this article are two classes of Rankin-Selberg
L-unctions, namely L(s, f \times g) and L(s, sym^2(g) \times sym^2(g)), where
f, g are newforms, holomorphic or of Maass type, on the upper half plane, and
sym^2(g) denotes the symmetric square lift of g to GL(3). We prove that in
general, i.e., when these L-functions are not divisible by L-functions of
quadratic characters (such divisibility happening rarely), they do not admit
any Landau-Siegel zeros. These zeros, which are real and close to s=1, are
highly mysterious and are not expected to occur. There are corollaries of our
result, one of them being a strong lower bound for special value at s=1, which
is of interest both geometrically and analytically. One also gets this way a
good bound on the norm of sym^2(g).

fulltext:
arXiv:math/0108054v1 [math.NT] 8 Aug 2001

ON THE EXCEPTIONAL ZEROS OF RANKIN-SELBERG
L-FUNCTIONS
DINAKAR RAMAKRISHNAN AND SONG WANG

Introduction
In this paper we study the possibility of real zeros near s = 1 for the RankinSelberg L-functions L(s, f × g) and L(s, sym2 (g) × sym2 (g)), where f, g are newforms, holomorphic or otherwise, on the upper half plane H, and sym2 (g) denotes
the automorphic form on GL(3)/Q associated to g by Gelbart and Jacquet ([GJ79]).
We prove that the set of such zeros of these L-functions is the union of the corresponding sets for L(s, χ) with χ a quadratic Dirichlet character, which divide them.
Such a divisibility does not occur in general, for example when f, g are of level 1.
When f is a Maass form for SL(2, Z) of Laplacian eigenvalue λ, this leads to a sharp
lower bound, in terms of λ, for the norm of sym2 (f ) on GL(3)/Q, analogous to the
well known and oft-used result for the Petersson norm of f proved in [HL94] and
[GHLL94]. As a consequence of our result on L(s, sym2 (g) × sym2 (g)) one gets a
good upper bound for the spectrally normalized first coefficient a(1, 1) of sym2 (g).
(In the artihmetic normalization, a(1, 1) would be 1.) In a different direction, we
are able to show that the symmetric sixth and eighth power L-functions of modular
forms f with trivial character (Haupttypus) are holomorphic in (1− logcM , 1), where
M is the thickened conductor (see section 1) and c a universal, positive, effective
constant; by a recent theorem of Kim and Shahidi ([KSh2001]), one knows that
these L-functions are invertible in R(s) ≥ 1 except possibly for a pole at s = 1. If
f runs over holomorphic newforms of a fixed weight (resp. level), for example, the
thickened conductor M is essentially the level (resp. weight). We will in general
work over arbitrary number fields and use the adelic language.
First some preliminaries. Suppose D(s) is any Dirichlet series given as an Euler
product in {R(s) > 1}, which admits a meromorphic continuation to the whole
s-plane with no pole outside s = 1, together with a functional equation relating s
to 1 − s after adding suitable archimedean factors. By an exceptional zero, or a
Siegel zero, or perhaps more appropriately (cf. [IwS2000]) a Landau-Siegel zero, of
D(s), one means a real zero s = β of D(s) which is close to s = 1. More precisely,
such a zero will lie in (1 − logCM , 1), where C is an effective, universal constant > 0
(see section 1). The Grand Riemann Hypothesis (GRH) would imply that there
should be no such an exceptional zero, but it is of course quite hard to verify.
It was shown in [HRa95] that for any number field F , the L-function L(s, π)
of a cusp form π in GL(2)/F admits no Landau-Siegel zero. In the special case
when π is dihedral, i.e., associated to a character χ of a quadratic extension K of
F , L(s, π) is simply the abelian L-function L(s, χ) considered by Hecke, and if θ is

D.Ramakrishnan and S.Wang

the non-trivial automorphism of K/F , the cuspidality of π forces χ to be distinct
from χ ◦ θ. We will say that π is of type (K/F, χ) in this case.
It was also shown in [HRa95] that for any n > 1, the standard L-series L(s, π) of
cusp forms π on GL(n)/F admit no Landau-Siegel zero if one assumes Langlands's
principle of functoriality, in particular the existence of the automorphic tensor
product. An analogous, but slightly more complicated, statement can be made for
general Rankin-Selberg L-series on GL(n)×GL(m), but assuming the full force of
functoriality is but a distant dream at the moment, though it is highly instructive to
be aware of what it entails. So it becomes an interesting problem to know how much
one can unconditionally prove by making use of available instances of functoriality;
the method has to deviate some from that given in [HRa95]. This is what we carry
out here for n = m ≤ 3.
Roughly speaking, the main point is to find a suitable positive Dirichlet series
D(s) which is divisible by the L(s) of interest to a degree k, say, which is (strictly)
larger than the order of pole of D(s) at s = 1. If there is anything creative here, at
all, it is in the proper choice of D(s) and then in the verification of the holomorphy
of D(s)/L(s)k , at least in a real interval (t, 1) for a fixed t < 1. It should be noted,
however, that this approach fails to give anything significant for L-functions of
quadratic characters; for two very interesting, and completely different, approaches
for this crucial case see [IwS2000] and [GS2000].
Now fix a number field F and consider the Rankin-Selberg L-function L(s, π×π ′ )
associated to a pair (π, π ′ ) of cusp forms on GL(2)/F . Denote by ω, resp. ω ′ , the
central character of π, resp. π ′ . Our first main result is the following
Theorem A Let π, π ′ be cuspidal automorphic representations of GL(2, AF ).
Then L(s, π × π ′ ) admits no Landau-Siegel zero except possibly in the following
cases:
(i) π is non-dihedral and π ′ ≃ π ⊗ μ with ωμ of order ≤ 2;
(ii) π, resp. π ′ , is dihedral of type (K, χ), resp. (K ′ , χ′ ), with K ′ = K and χ′ χ
or χ′ (χ ◦ θ) of order ≤ 2.
In case (i), resp. (ii), the exceptional zeros of L(s, π × π ′ ) are the same as those of
L(s, ωμ), resp. L(s, χ′ χ)L(s, χ′ (χ ◦ θ)). In case (ii), if χ′ χ or χ′ (χ ◦ θ) is trivial,
then the exceptional zeros are the same as those of ζK (s). In either case, there is
at most one exceptional zero.
For the vast majority of cases not satisfying (i) or (ii), L(s, π × π ′ ) has no
exceptional zero. In particular, if π0 , π0′ are fixed, non-dihedral cusp forms on
GL(2)/F which are not twist equivalent to each other, there exists an effective
constant c > 0 such that the family L(s, π0 × (π0′ ⊗ χ)), with χ running over
quadratic characters

The non-existence of Landau-Siegel zeros for L(s, sym2 (π)) (for π non-dihedral)
has been known for a while by the important work of Goldfeld, Hoffstein, Lieman
and Lockart ([GHLL94]). For general μ, the non-existence for L(s, sym2 (π) ⊗ μ) is
known by [Ba97], following an earlier reduction step given in section 6 of [HRa95].
So our Theorem is not new in this case.

3

For any cusp form π on GL(2)/F , let L(s, π; symn ) denote, for every n ≥ 1, the
symmetric n-th power L-function of π (see section 1 for a definition). It is expected
that there is an automorphic form symn (π) on GL(n + 1)/F whose standard Lfunction coincides with L(s, π; symn ). This is classical ([GJ79]) for n = 2 and a
major breakthrough has been made recently for n = 3 ([KSh2000]) and for n =
4 ([K2000]). The proof of Theorem A uses the result for n = 3 as well as the
construction of the first author ([Ra2000]) of the Rankin-Selberg product of pairs
(π, π ′ ) of forms on GL(2)/F as an automorphic form π ⊠ π ′ on GL(4)/F .
Recall that π is dihedral iff it admits a self-twist by a non-trivial, necessarily
quadratic, character. One says that it is tetrahedral, resp. octahedral, iff sym2 (π),
resp. sym3 (π), is cuspidal and admits a non-trivial self-twist by a cubic, resp.
quadratic character. It is well known that sym2 (π) is cuspidal ([GJ79]) iff π is
not dihedral. It has been shown in [KSh2000], resp. [KSh2001], that sym3 (π),
resp. sym4 (π), is cuspidal iff π is not dihedral or tetrahedral, resp. not dihedral,
tetrahedral or octahedral. We will henceforth say that a cusp form π on GL(2)/F
is of solvable polydedral type if it is either dihedral or tetrahedral or octahedral. Our
second main result is the following:
Theorem B Let π be a self-dual cuspidal automorphic representation of GL(2, AF ).
Then the set of Landau-Siegel zeros of L(s, sym2 (π) × sym2 (π)) is the union of the
sets of Landau-Siegel zeros of abelian L-functions of the form L(s, χ), χ2 = 1, which
divide L(s, sym2 (π) × sym2 (π)), if any. Moreover, if π is not of solvable polyhedral
type and if ζF (s) has no exceptional zero (for example when F = Q), then there is
no exceptional zero.
This theorem holds also for any cuspidal π on GL(2)/F which is a unitary
character twist of a selfdual representation.
The following corollary of Theorem B gives precise bounds for the Petersson
norm on GL(3)/Q of the symmetric square of a Maass wave form g of level 1. In
Section 6 (see Definition 6.3), we will define a suitably normalized function sym2 (g)
spanning the space of the Gelbart-Jacquet square lift to GL(3)/Q of the cuspidal
automorphic representation π generated by g.
Corollary C Let g be a Maass form on the upper half plane H, relative to SL(2, Z),
of weight zero and Laplacian eigenvalue λ, which is also an eigenfunction of Hecke
operators. Then for each ε > 0,

Our proof of Theorem B will establish on the way that the symmetric 4-th power
L-function of any self-dual cusp form π on GL(2), not of solvable polyhedral type,
admits no Landau-Siegel zero. A slew of interesting results for the L(s, π; symn ) for

Theorem D Let F be a number field and π a self-dual cusp form on GL(2)/F of
thickened conductor M . Then there exists a universal, effective constant c > 0 such
that L(s, π; sym6 ) and L(s, π; sym8 ) have no pole in the real interval (1 − logcM , 1).
Now we will say a few words about the proofs.
Regarding Theorem A, suppose we are in the main case, i.e., neither π nor π ′ is
dihedral and also π ′ is not isomorphic to π ⊗ μ for any character μ. Under these
hypotheses, π ⊠ π ′ is cuspidal on GL(4)/F by [Ra2000]. When it is not self-dual,
there is a simple argument (see section 3 of [HRa95]) to deduce the non-existence
of a Siegel zero. So we may assume that π ⊠ π ′ is self-dual, which implies that the
central characters ω, ω ′ of π, π ′ are inverses of each other. For simplicity assume
for the moment that ω, ω ′ are trivial. (For a full treatment of the general case, see
section 4.) Then the key point is to appeal to the following identity of L-functions

In order to prove Corollary C, we begin by deducing a precise relationship between the Peterson norm of a suitably mormalized sym2 (g) (see section 6) and
L(s, sym2 (g) × sym2 (g)) by using the results on its integral representation due to
Jacquet, Piatetski-Shapiro and Shalika ([JPSS83], [JS90]), and an exact formula
of E. Stade for pairs of spherical representations of GL(3, R) ([St93], [St2001]).
More precisely, ( sym2 (g), sym2 (g) ) differs Ress=1 L(s, sym2 (g) × sym2 (g)) by a
constant factor coming from the residue of an Eisenstein series. (There should
also be a similar result when f is a holomorphic newform for SL(2, Z), but at this
point one does not appear to know enough about the archimedean zeta integral on
GL(3)×GL(3) to achieve this.) Finally, the nonexistence of Landau-Siegel zeros for
L(s, sym2 (g) × sym2 (g)) allows us to bound from below its residue at s = 1, and
this in turn gives us, when sym2 (g) is replaced by its spectral normalization, the
desired bound on the first Fourier coefficient a(1, 1). For details, see Section 6.
To prove Theorem D we appeal to the factorization of L(s, sym4 (π); Λ2 ) above
as well as to the identity

For any cuspidal automorphic representation Π of GL(n, AF ), if S denotes the
union of the archimedean places of F with the set of finite places where Π is
ramified, one knows by Bump-Ginzburg ([BuG92]) that the incomplete L-function
LS (s, Π; sym2 ), defined in a right half plane by the Euler product over places outside
S, is holomorphic in (1/2, 1). Applying this with n = 4, Π = sym4 (π), and carefully
taking care of the factors at S, we deuce the holomorphy of the syemmetric square
L-function of sym4 (π). Now the knowledge gained from the proof of Theorem B on
Landau-Siegel zeros of L(s, sym4 (π)) allows us (see section 7) to prove Theorem D.

Call an L(s) ∈ D primitive if it cannot be factored as L1 (s)L2 (s) with L1 (s), L2 (s)
non-scalar in D. The Dirichlet and Hecke L-functions, as well as those of cusp forms
on the upper half plane are primitive.
Conjecture I Every L(s) ǫ Dm is quasi-automorphic, ie, there exists an automorphic form π on GL(m)/Q such that Lp (s) = L(s, πp ) for almost all p. Moreover,
L(s) is primitive iff π is cuspidal.
This is compatible with Langlands philosophy ([La70]) and with the conjecture of
Cogdell and Piatetski-Shapiro ([CoPS94]); Cogdell has remarked to us recently that
Piatetski-Shapiro has also formulated (unpublished) a similar conjecture involving
analogs of D. Note such a thing cannot be formulated over number fields of degree
> 1 as one can permute the Euler factors lying over any given rational prime.
Also, there exists an example of Patterson over function fields F over a finite field
Fq satisfying analogous conditions, but with zeros on the lines Re(s) = 1/4 and
Re(s) = 3/4. One problem in characteristic p is that there is no minimal global
field F such as Q. It is still an interesting open problem to know if one can define
a good notion of "primitivity" over function fields.
Conjecture II For any L(s) ∈ D, if it has a pole of order r at s = 1, then
ζ(s)r |L(s), ie., L(s) = ζ(s)r L1 (s), with L1 (s) ǫ D.
This is compatible with the conjectures of Selberg, Tate and Langlands.

Definition 1.5 Let c > 0. Then we say that L(s) has a Landau-Siegel zero relative
to c if L(β) = 0 for some β ∈ (1 − logcM , 1).
Definition 1.6 Let F be a family, by wich we will mean a class of L-functions in
D with M → ∞ in F . We say that F admits no Landau-Siegel Zero if there exists
an effective constant c > 0 such that no L(s) in F has a zero in (1 − logcM , 1).
The general expectation is framed by the following
Conjecture III Let F be a family in D. Then F admits no Landau-Siegel zero.

One reason for interest in this is that the lack of such a zero implies a good lower
bound for L(s) at s = 1. Note that in view of Conjecture I, the Grand Riemann
Hypothesis, shortened as GRH, implies that all the non-trivial zeros of any L(s) in
D lie on the critical line, hence it implies Conjecture III. Of course the GRH is but
a distant goal at the moment, and it is hopefully of interest to verify Conjecture
III for various families.
The L-functions of pure motives over Q, in particular those associated to the cohomology of smooth projective varieties X/Q, are expected to be automorphic and
hence should belong to D. For these L-functions, when they are of even Frobenius
weight, the values at s = 1 have arithmetic significance by the general Bloch-Kato
conjectures, and so the question of non-existence of Landau-Siegel zeros is helpful
to understand from a purely arithmetical point of view.
We will need the following useful (and well known) fact:
Lemma 1.7 Let L(s) ǫ Dm be a positive Dirichlet series having a pole of order
r ≥ 1 at s = 1, with L′ (s)/L(s) < 0 for real s in (1, ∞). Then there exists an
effective constant C > 0, depending only on m and r, such that L(s) has most r
real zeros in (1 − logCM , 1).
For a more relaxed discussion of these matters, see the expository article [Ra99]
on the Landau-Siegel zeros, as well as the articles [GHLL94] and [HRa95].

3. Some useful instances of functoriality
Here we summarize certain known instances, which we will need, of functorial
transfer of automorphic forms from one group to another.
Let π, π ′ be cuspidal automorphic representations of GL(n, AF ), GL(m, AF ), and
let r, r′ be C-representations of GL(n, C), GL(m, C) of dimension d, d′ respectively.
The Langlands philosophy then predicts that there exists an isobaric automorphic
representation r(π) ⊠ r′ (π ′ ) of GL(dd′ , AF ) such that
(3.1)

L(s, r(π) ⊠ r′ (π ′ )) = L(s, π × π ′ ; r ⊗ r′ ).

When it is known to exist, the map π → r(π) will be called a functorial transfer
attached to r; some also call it a lifting.This is far from being known in this generality, but nevertheless, there have been some notable instances of progress wwhich
we will make use of. Sometimes we do not know r(π) exists, but still one has some
good properties of thee relevant L-functions.

7. Proof of Theorem D
Let π be a cuspidal automorphic representation of GL(2, AF ) of trivial central
character. Denote by S the union of the set S∞ of archimedean places of FQ

set of finite places where π is ramified. Given any Euler product L(s) = v Lv (s)
over F , we will write LS (s) to mean the (incomplete Euler) product of Lv (s) over
all v outside S.
Next recall (see section 3) that for every j ≤ 4, there is an isobaric auutomorphic
representation symj (π) of GL(j+1, AF ), established long ago for j = 2 by S. Gelbart
and H. Jacquet [GJ77], and very recently for j = 3, resp. j = 4, by H. Kim and F.
Shahidi ([KSh2000]), resp. H. Kim ([K2000]), such that
L(s, symj (π)) = L(s, π, symj ).

Lemma 7.4 Let π be a cuspidal automorphic representation of GL(2, AF ) with
trivial central character, and let v be a place where πv is a ramified, non-tempered
principal series representatin. Then sym4 (π) is unramified at v.

Lemma 7.9 Let π be a cuspidal automorphic representation of GL(2, AF ), and v a
place of F where πv is tempered. Then for any j ≥ 1, the local factor L(s, πv , symj )
is holomorphic in R(s) > 1/2 except for a possible pole at s = 1..

Proof.
If v is archimedean, or if v is finite but πv is not special, πv corresponds to a 2-dimensional representation σv of the local Weil group WFv . The
temperedness of πv implies that σv has bounded image in GL(2, C). Then for any
finite-dimensional C-representation r of dimension N , in particular for symj , of
GL(2, C), the image of r(σv ) will be bounded, and this implies that the admissible,
irreducible representation Πv of GL(N, Fv ), associated to r(σv ) by the local Langlands correspondence, is tempered. Then L(s, Πv ) is holomorphic in R(s) > 1/2
except for a possible pole at s = 1 (see [BaR94]). (One can also prove directly,
using the extension in [De73] of Brauer's theorem to the representations of WFv ,
that L(s, r(σv ) has the requisite property.) We are now done in this case because
L(s, πv ; symj ) is defined to be L(s, symj (σv )).
So we may take v to be finite and assume that πv is a special representaton
sp(μv ) (see [HRa95], setion 2 for notation), associated to the partition 2 = 1 + 1
and a (unitary) character μv of Fv∗ . Then the associated σv is of the form (w, g) →
μv (w) ⊗ g, for all w in WFv and g in SL(2, C). So we have
symj (σv ) ≃ μjv ⊗ symj ,

which corresponds to the special representation sp(μjv ) of GL(j + 1, Fv ) associated
to the partition j + 1 = 1 + . . . + 1 and the character μjv . Now we may appeal to
the fact (see [BaR94]) that for any unitary character νv , the function L(s, sp(νv ))
is holomorphic in R(s) > 0.
Having established these preliminary lemmas, we are ready to begin the proof of
Theorem D. Let S denote the union of the archimedean places of F with the set of
finite places v where πv is ramified and tempered. In view of Lemma 7.9, it suffices
to show the following
Proposition 7.10 The incomplete L-function LS (s, π; sym6 ) is holomorphic in
the real interval (1 − logcM , 1) for a positive, effective constant c independent of
π, with M denoting the thickened conductor of π. The same result holds for the

 Exceptional zeros of Rankin-Selberg L-functions

29

symmetric 8th power L-function if F is a Galois extension of Q not containing any
quadratic extension of Q.
Proof. When π is of solvable polyhedral type, the results of Kim and Shahidi in
[Ksh2001] imply that LS (s, π; symj ) is holomorphic in (1/2, 1) for any j ≤ 9. So we
may assume that we are not in this case, so that sym4 (π) is a cuspidal automorphic
representation of GL(5, AF ).
By the definition of S, given any place v outside S, πv is either unramified or
a ramified, non-tempered principal series representation. Thanks to Lemma 7.4,
sym4 (πv ) is unramified in either case. So we may appeal to the work of BumpGinzburg ([BuG92]) on the symmetric square L-fnctions, we get the holomorphy in
(1/2, 1) of the incomplete L-functions LS (s, sym4 (π); Λ2 ) and LS (s, sym4 (π); sym2 ).
Next we appeal to the identities of Lemma 7.1 with T = S. The assertion
of the Proposition is then clear for the symmetric 6-th power L-function since
LS (s, sym2 (π)) admits no Landau-Siegel zero by [GHLL94]. So let us turn our
attention to the (incomplete) symmetric 8-th power L-function of π. It suffices, by
the identity (ii) of Lemma 7.1, that it suffices to show that LS (s, sym4 (π))ζFS (s)
admits no Landau-Siegel zero. Since F is by hypothesis a Galois extension of Q
not containing any quadratic field, one knows by Stark ([St]) that ζFS (s) admits no
Landau-Siegel zero. So we are finally done by our proof of Theorem B, where we
showed that LS (s, sym4 (π)) admits no Landau-Siegel zero. Strictly speaking, we
showed it for the full L-function. But the local factors at S, being tempered, do
not have any pole in (1/2, 1).
